journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part P: Journal of Sports Engineering and Technology

title-group.article-title: The biomechanical design of a gymnastics training aid for a handstand on the rings

article-meta.aff: 1School of Sport, Exercise and Health Sciences, Loughborough University, Loughboough, UK.
2Wolfson School of Mechanical and Manufacturing Engineering, Loughborough University, Loughborough, UK.

author-notes.corresp: *School of Sport, Exercise and Health Sciences, Loughborough University, Ashby Road, Loughborough, Leicestershire LE11 3TU, UK. email: m.r.yeadon@lboro.ac.uk

abstract.p: The handstand on rings is a requirement in competition routines in Men’s Artistic Gymnastics, and hence is a key skill in the development of an elite artistic gymnast. This study was carried out to establish the coaching requirements of a training aid for a handstand on the rings, to investigate the biomechanics of the handstand, to design and construct a training aid, and to assess its performance. The key requirements of a training aid for a handstand on rings were compiled from a survey of 11 national coaches. A biomechanical analysis of a handstand on rings was carried out in order to investigate the control mechanism and to inform the training aid design. The aid was designed to permit the same control mechanism to be used and was manufactured in accordance with British Standards. In order to assess the performance of the aid displacement, joint angle, and muscle activation data were used to compare handstands on the rings, floor, prototype training aid, and two other existing training aids. The results showed that a handstand on the prototype was more similar to rings than a handstand on the existing training aids. The prototype also simplified the learning of the skill.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: In Men’s Artistic Gymnastics, the handstand is a requirement in all elite competition rings routines. The skill is a balance element which requires the gymnast to support himself on his hands on two moving pendulums. This skill differs from a handstand on the floor since the rings are free to move. Both balances require continual control by means of varying joint torques. During the handstand on the floor, torque produced at the wrist is used to control the balance [1]. However this technique cannot be used to the control the handstand on rings as there is no fixed surface against which to produce the torque. The rings handstand (Fig. 1) requires the control of the balance to be produced via changes in shoulder angle [2], keeping the rings beneath the mass centre, and hence is controlled primarily through shoulder torque variation.

An additional problem with learning the handstand on the rings is the number of degrees of freedom that are inherently involved in this skill, and their need to be controlled by the gymnast in order to maintain balance. There is also the problem of the rings being capable of swinging during performances, and as a result of these complications this skill is heavily reliant on coach support. Although a number of training aids exist for this skill, none replicates the free horizontal movement of the hands that occurs in a handstand on rings.

The aim of this study was to establish the coaching requirements of a training aid for a handstand on the rings, to base the design of a training aid for the rings handstand upon a theoretical analysis of the control required for this skill, to construct a prototype training aid, and to then assess the prototype with respect to the coaching requirements.

sec.title: 2 Methods
sec.p: A training aid for rings handstand was designed so as to use the same basic (shoulder) control mechanism to preserve a balance as is used during a full performance of the skill on rings. A structured survey was conducted on 11 national coaches during elite squad training sessions in which each coach identified the technique used in a handstand on rings, the shortcomings of existing training aids, and the requirements of an ideal training aid. From these interviews the four most frequent requirement responses were identified as the key requirements for the prototype rings handstand training aid. A theoretical analysis of a handstand on a frictionless surface (the proposed design) was carried out, and this model was compared to a model of a handstand on rings. Displacement, force, and muscle data were collected and were used, together with the identified key requirements, to compare handstands by a competitive gymnast on the rings, floor, prototype training aid, and two other existing training aids.

sec.title: 2.1 Model of handstand on a frictionless surface
sec.p: The handstand on rings is controlled by moving the hands in front and behind the mass centre. A training aid should permit the same kind of control, for example using frictionless movement of the hands. A comparative study of the handstand on rings and the proposed training aid was undertaken.

Since a handstand on the rings is controlled primarily through variation of the shoulder angle [2], a two segment body model with a single joint was used. The arm segment, A, represented the hands and arms while the body segment, B, represented the remainder of the gymnast, the two segments being connected at a shoulder joint, S (Fig. 2). It was assumed that there were no horizontal forces.

caption.p: Two segment model (A = arms, B = body) of the handstand on a surface free to move horizontally

sec.p: A net shoulder extension torque, T, was applied (closing the shoulder joint, S), in order to control the balance by ensuring that the whole body mass centre, G, was in close vertical alignment with the hands, O. The method used to obtain the equations of motion for this system was similar to that of [1], for the control of a handstand on the floor which resulted in an equation of motion of the form x··=k2x−eT, where T was the wrist torque, x was the mass centre horizontal displacement and k and e were constants. For this system stable control can be effected using control in the form T=px+dx· providing the time delay is not too great. It was anticipated that a similar equation of motion could be obtained for the handstand on a frictionless surface using shoulder torque to control the system.
During a handstand on a frictionless surface, as the mass centre does not move horizontally, x·G=x··G=0, and all measurements are made from a fixed location, so without loss of generality xG=0.
Taking moments about S for the body segment B (Fig. 2) gives

sec.title: 2.2 Control strategy for a handstand on a frictionless surface
sec.p: From (8) the displacement, X, of the system is governed by the equation
where t is the time.

It was shown in [1], that such a system may be controlled using closed loop proportional plus derivative control in which the torque, T, is a linear function of displacement and velocity at an earlier time

Substitution of (11) in (10) gives the equation for damped simple harmonic motion which will result in stable control if all coefficients are positive. It has been shown [1] that there are ranges of values for p and d which achieve this and that the limiting value of t0 is t0 = √2/k. Control is not possible for values of t0 greater than this.

sec.title: 2.3 Comparison of the mechanics of the handstand on training aid and rings
sec.p: The frictionless model of a handstand differs from a model of a handstand on rings in two respects. First the frictionless model does not include the pendulum effect of the rings' cables and second the moment arm of the force, F, about the mass centre, G, (Fig. 3) is larger for the frictionless model for a given displacement of the hands, O, away from PG. In other respects the two models are very similar.

caption.p: Comparison of (a) the rings model and (b) the training aid model. In (a) P is the suspension point for the rings cables. In (b) P is vertically above the mass centre G

sec.p: For the model of the rings, fictitious forces mrθ·2 and m(rθ··+2r·θ·) must be introduced radially and tangentially into the moving reference frame, PG, in order that Newton’s Second Law still holds. Resolving parallel to PG in the moving reference frame
whereas for the training aid model

Equations (15) and (16) are very similar, except that equation (15) includes the effects of θ1 and θ2. Since θ1 and θ2 are assumed to be small, Fcosθ2 is approximated as F and mgcosθ1+mrθ·12 is approximated as mg.
Resolving perpendicular to PG in the moving reference frame of the rings model

but equivalently x··=0, since x=0 in the moving reference frame. For the training aid model mx··=0 since there are no horizontal forces. Consequently the tangential equation of motion is the same for the rings in this reference frame and for the training aid.

Next consider the controlling moment of the force, F, about the mass centre, G, in the two models due to the displacement of the hands, O, away from the reference line, PG (Fig. 3). In the case of the frictionless training aid, F will have a moment, Fd, about G, where d is the distance of the hands, O, from the vertical line, PG. For the rings model, if d is again the distance of the hands, O, from the line, PG, the moment arm of F about G will be proportionally smaller in the ratio of the distances PG and PO (about 2:3). As a consequence the hands will have to move more in the case of the rings handstand to produce an equivalent restoring torque.

Thus it is to be expected that the same kind of control will be used on the rings as on the training aid. If low frequencies associated with the pendulum swing of the rings are removed the resulting displacement data should be very similar to that of the training aid. Finally, using anthropometric data of the gymnast, the individual body segment masses, positions of mass centres, lengths, and inertia parameters were then calculated using an inertia model [3] in order to obtain a value for the maximum feedback time delay, t0.

sec.title: 2.4 Training aid design
sec.p: The design process and analytical approach implemented was similar to the methodology for the design of a previous training aid [4]. The first stage in the design process was to identify the crucial components of the design for a prototype training aid to help gymnasts learn a handstand on the rings. A design strategy was developed to include such information as was obtained from literature, from the gymnast performance data collections, and from relevant British Standard requirements [5]. This approach used specific expert knowledge of both the skill technique and developmental needs, alongside a biomechanical analysis of the skill in order to determine the design criteria, and key training aid requirements.

The training aid was designed so as to have minimal resistance to movement of the hands horizontally based on the results of the mechanical analyses in 2.2 and 2.3. The four key requirements of the rings handstand training aid were identified from the coach survey as being: to simplify the task, to utilize the same control as used during a rings handstand, to provide progressive learning levels, and to provide a safe environment in which the gymnast could practise the skill. The training aid was consequentially designed with the six required degrees of freedom: independent left–right lateral, forward–backward, and rotational displacement with the ability to remove degrees of freedom independently, whilst remaining at ground level.

sec.title: 2.5 Data collection
sec.p: Data were collected in order to compare the control strategies adopted during the performance of handstands on the rings, the floor, the prototype training aid, and two other training aids. During the initial data collection typical inertia values for an international competitive male artistic gymnast (age = 28 years, mass = 75.6 kg, height = 1.76 m) were obtained from anthropometric measurements using an inertia model [3]. The segmental inertia values were used to calculate λ in equations (5) and (6), k and e in equation (8), and the limiting value of t0.

In accordance with University Ethical Advisory Committee procedure, informed consent was obtained from the male gymnast. Sixteen reflective markers were placed lateral to the joint centres of the wrist, elbow, shoulder, hip, knee, ankle, and metatarsophalangeal joints on both the left and right sides of the body, and on the forehead and the opposing position on the back of the head. Markers were also positioned on each of the training aids and on the rings' cables during the data collection to enable an analysis of the motion of the training aids.

Three-dimensional coordinate data of the markers were collected at 100 Hz using a Vicon 624 Motion Capture System, consisting of eight 1280 by 1024 pixel MOS infrared M2 cameras with 24–70 mm zoom lenses. Whole body mass centre coordinates were calculated from the marker data using the segmental masses and mass centre locations.

Muscle activation data were also collected at a frequency of 100 Hz using a Bio-Vision EMG system. Disposable surface electrodes were positioned in pairs over the belly of the muscle, perpendicular to the direction of the muscle fibres. EMG was obtained at the extensor carpi radialis longus, flexor carpi radialis, and flexor carpi ulnaris for wrist movement, and at the anterior deltoid, medial deltoid, and the posterior deltoid for shoulder movement.

Signal amplifiers with attached gain switches were connected to the electrodes, to ensure that even a small signal would be detected. Maximum voluntary contractions (MVC) were performed for up to five seconds with arms overhead either standing or lying with an assistant providing stabilizing support prior to handstand trials to enable the re-scaling of the EMG readings to a percentage reference value. A single square pulse wave was sent to the analogue port on the Vicon data-station in order to synchronize the EMG data and Vicon data during the data collection. EMG recordings of MVC were full wave rectified and low pass filtered at 10 Hz using a fourth order phaseless Butterworth filter. MVC was calculated by averaging over an interval for which there was no obvious fall in magnitude. EMG recordings on the apparatus were full wave rectified and low pass filtered and then normalized to MVC. Mean normalized EMG values were determined for a period of 10 s during each balance.

Handstand balances were performed on the rings, the prototype training aid, the Janssen–Fritsen handstand rocker, the Janssen–Fritsen handstand bowls (Fig. 4), and on the floor. Three trials were performed on each apparatus and data were taken from the best trial of the three as identified by an international judge. For the prototype trials four settings were used with one, two, four, and six degrees of freedom. Fourier cosine series were fitted to the data collected on the rings handstand and terms corresponding to time periods greater than two seconds were deleted to remove the effects of cable swing which had a time period of 3s.

caption.p: Rocker and bowls training aids for handstand on rings

sec.p: The data from the handstand balances were compared to investigate the variations in the control mechanism adopted during the performances on each piece of equipment. The wrist and mass centre displacements, shoulder and hip angle ranges of motion, and muscle activation measurements were used to evaluate differences within the performance of the handstand on the three training aids and the performance of a handstand on rings and a handstand on the floor. All four pieces of equipment were also assessed against the identified coaches’ key requirements.

sec.title: 3 Results
sec.p: The prototype training aid could be used at floor level (Fig. 5) and had the required six degrees of freedom, allowing the hands to move forwards–backwards, left–right, and rotate (Fig. 6). This was achieved using a pair of roller bearing rails for the forwards–backwards movement of each hand, a single rail for left–right movement of each hand, and a vertical axis of rotation for the handgrip of each hand (Fig. 6). Each degree of freedom could be removed by locking in a fixed position and the forward–backward motion of each hand could be constrained to move together by use of a bar which could connect the two units. The degrees of freedom could be introduced progressively starting with only the forward–backward-linked motion, introducing left–right movement of each hand, followed by rotation of each hand, and finally allowing independent forward–backward movement of each hand.

caption.p: A handstand on the training aid
Prototype training aid with six degrees of freedom

sec.title: 3.1 Inertia data
sec.p: Using the segmental inertia parameters calculated from the anthropometric measurements of the male artistic gymnast, the inertia parameters of the two segment model were calculated (Table 1).

caption.p: Inertia parameters for the two segment model: A = arms, B = remainder of the body

sec.p: Hence substituting into equation (9) gives A = 2.43; B = 1.34; C = 15.73; D = 14.39; E = 41.76; and F = 37.69, when

where ma is the mass of the two arms (segment A), and mb is the mass of segment B. Calculating λ from equation (9) gives λ = –0.9097, e = –0.0012, k = 0.89, and t0 = 1.58 s; or λ = 0.098, where e = 0.1333, k = 3.11, and t0 = 0.45 s.

sec.title: 3.2 Data analysis
sec.p: During the handstand on the rings the EMG data collected from the wrist showed only tremor due to co-contraction of the muscles [6–8], whereas on the floor the EMG data indicated the use of wrist control (Table 2). On all three training aids there is evidence of higher shoulder EMG (from the anterior deltoid) than on the floor. Thus all three training aids encourage greater use of the shoulder than for a handstand on the floor.

caption.p: Movement of mass centre, wrist, shoulder and hip; EMG of wrist and shoulder

fn.p: Note: prototype values are the means of the four settings

sec.p: On the rings the mass centre moved only 10 mm, and the wrists moved 100 mm as expected due to the control of the balance being through variation of shoulder angle. On the floor the mass centre moved 20 mm, and there was no substantial movement of the wrists. The mass centre displacement results from all three training aids showed more mass centre movement than the rings (Table 2). All three training aids exhibited greater wrist movement than for a handstand on the floor.

The range of movement at the shoulder was greater for the rings and the prototype than for the floor, rocker, or bowls (Table 2). The range of movement at the hip joint was greater for the rings, the prototype and the bowls than for the floor or rocker. Indeed there was greater movement at the hip than at the shoulder for the rings and the three training aids suggesting that the hip joint made substantial contributions to the control of balance as well as the shoulder joint.

sec.title: 4 Discussion
sec.p: The performance of a handstand on the rings was shown to be mechanically similar to a handstand on a frictionless surface for which a control strategy using shoulder torque was identified. A prototype training aid (Fig. 5) was developed based on these findings, and on the collated coaches’ requirements.

The performances on the rings and the three training aids all exhibited greater movement of the wrist, shoulder, and hip compared to a handstand on the floor. The EMG data also indicate that more use is made of the shoulder than for a handstand on the floor. This reflects the fact that handstands on such apparatus are more difficult to balance than a handstand on the floor and suggests that all three training aids encourage use of the shoulder (and hip) joints for controlling balance.

The rocker shows less shoulder and hip movement compared to the rings, prototype, and bowls, and is more similar in this respect to a handstand on the floor. Although the wrists move an appropriate amount in the rocker handstand, this is a function of the equipment rotating rather than the wrists being free to move horizontally. The bowls did not exhibit much more shoulder involvement than on the floor although the hips did move much more.

The prototype was more like a handstand on rings than the other two training aids with respect to shoulder movement and hip movement (Table 2). Additionally the degrees of freedom provided by the prototype were more similar to the rings in that the hands were free to move forwards and backwards. The prototype also provided lateral freedom of hand movement as well as rotational movement of each hand as on the rings. Thus although all three training aids encourage the use of shoulder movement only the prototype provides similar degrees of freedom to the rings. While the data collected were only from one experienced international gymnast, the advantages identified for the training aid are based largely upon the mechanical similarities to the handstand on rings and on the similar degrees of freedom available. The extent to which the new training aid poses an advantage over the rocker and bowls will only be discovered once it is used to introduce the handstand on rings to novice gymnasts.

As the training aid removed the inherent swinging of the rings it simplified the handstand. It also simplified the balancing task by permitting the various degrees of freedom to be introduced separately and individually (Fig. 6) and successfully fulfilled all of the identified coaches’ requirements, whereas the rings and the two Janssen–Fritsen training aids did not allow progressive learning or skill simplification. When demonstrated to John Atkinson (FIG Technical Committee), his comment was: ‘so simple yet so brilliant, this will be a very useful piece of training equipment for gymnasts’.
